questions.question: Question 1: What proportion of healthcare waste is hazardous waste?
questions.explanation:
15% of health care waste is hazardous waste. It may be infectious, toxic, or radioactive in nature. 
The remaining 85% is general, non-hazardous waste. Bio-medical waste means any waste that is generated during: • Diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of human beings or animals • Research activities pertaining thereto • Production or testing of biologicals Bio-medical waste is handled as per the Bio-medical Waste Management Rules, 2016. However, 
these rules do not apply to the following: • Radioactive wastes • Hazardous chemicals • Solid wastes • Lead-acid batteries • Hazardous wastes • e-Waste • Hazardous microorganisms

questions.question: Question 2: Cytotoxic and expired drugs are disposed by:
questions.explanation:
Cytotoxic and expired drugs are collected in a yellow bag and then disposed of by incineration. Expired cytotoxic drugs are to be returned to the manufacturer and subjected to incineration, 
encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis. Other discarded medicines can be disposed by incineration.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following category of wastes are treated by autoclaving and microwaving?
questions.explanation:
The final treatment of catheters, urine bags, and gloves is done by autoclaving and microwaving. They belong to recyclable contaminated waste and are disposed of in a red bag. Option A: Human anatomical waste is disposed of by incineration. Option C: Cytotoxic and expired/discarded medicine is disposed of by incineration/plasma 
pyrolysis/disposal in a secured landfill. Option D: Microbiological waste such as culture plates and slides are pre-treated with 
nonchlorinated chemicals and later disposed of by incineration. 671 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: While working as a 1st-year resident in the labor ward, where would you dispose of the 
placenta following a delivery?
questions.explanation:
Human anatomical wastes, like the placenta, are discarded in a yellow bag and disposed of by 
incineration/ plasma pyrolysis/ deep burial.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements are true about yellow waste disposal bags?
questions.explanation:
Yellow waste disposal bags are made from non-chlorinated plastic material and chemical liquid 
wastes are collected in them. Chlorinated items, glass, metal, and rubber are not sent for incineration as incinerating them 
would produce carcinogenic gases. The right disposal methods of the other options are: • Animal anatomical waste - Collected in yellow bags and later sent for incineration. • Metallic body implants - Collected in cardboard boxes with blue coloured marking and sent for 
recycling following autoclaving. • PVC gloves - Collected in red bags and sent for autoclaving followed by shredding.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following should not be incinerated?
questions.explanation: Specimens of microorganisms and live or attenuated vaccines can be incinerated. Wastes that should not be incinerated are: • Sharps • Pressurized gas containers • Reactive chemical waste • Waste with heavy metals like mercury and cadmium • PVC • Photographic or radiographic waste

questions.question:
Question 7: An orthopedic resident has removed a ‰-wire from the fractured olecranon of a 13-year-old 
boy. Where should he discard this?
questions.explanation:
Metallic body implants are disposed of in cardboard boxes with blue-colored markings. The contents of the blue box are sent to Common Biomedical Waste Treatment and Disposal 
Facility (CBWTF). In the facility, these items are sterilized by autoclaving or microwaving and 
then sent for recycling. 672 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Blood bag is to be disposed in:
questions.explanation: Blood bag should be disposed off in the yellow bin.

questions.question:
Question 9: An HIV-positive man is brought to you following an accident. How would you discard his 
blood-soaked dressing material?

options.a: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
options.b: Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
options.c: Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
options.d: Pour 10% non chlorinated chemicals on the dressing material and send for incineration

questions.explanation:
The blood-soaked dressing material should be disposed of in a non-chlorinated yellow bag and 
sent for incineration. Pretreatment is not a requisite for incinerating soiled waste. Items that require pretreatment with non-chlorinated chemicals before incineration: • Used blood bags • Other infectious plastic and liquid wastes • Laboratory cultures, stocks, or specimens of microorganisms • Live or attenuated vaccines • Human and animal cell cultures used in research • Dishes, and devices used for cultures

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following disposal methods is not as per biomedical waste management 
guidelines?

options.a: Disposal of a dead fetus of 21 weeks in a yellow bag by deep burial in rural areas
options.b: Pre-treatment of laboratory cultures with non-chlorinated disinfectant
options.c: Disposal of a glass ampoule with its cytotoxic drug through incineration
options.d: Disposal of radiological waste by deep burial

questions.explanation:
Radiological waste is not considered biomedical waste. Hence, deep burial is not done. Disposal of radiological is covered under the provisions of the Atomic Energy Act. The radiological 
effluents are incinerated in a dedicated incinerator having off-gas cleaning facility. Another 
method is to convert the organic base into an aqueous form by treating it with sodium hydroxide. Option A: Dead fetuses under the age of viability are considered human anatomical waste. 
Anatomical waste can be disposed of by deep burial in rural areas, where a common biomedical 
treatment facility and incineration is not available. Option B: Laboratory cultures are classified under the category of microbiology, biotechnology, 
and other clinical laboratory waste. They are pretreated with a non-chlorinated disinfectant before 
they are sent for incineration. Option C: The cytotoxic drugs are disposed of along with their packaging, through incineration.

questions.question:
Question 11: You are asked to catheterize an HBsAg-positive man before hernia surgery. According to the 
BMW management rules, where would you dispose of the plastic cover of the catheter?
questions.explanation:
The outer plastic cover of the Foleys catheter is discarded in a black bag. Foleys catheters are packaged in plastic covers to keep them sterile. The plastic cover is not 
biomedical waste but is a part of general (municipal) waste. Hence, it is discarded in the black 
bag. The foleys catheter is disposed of in a red bag. 673 
Sold by @itachibot As per Bio-Medical Waste Management Rules, the general waste must be disposed of in green 
bins (for recyclable waste) and blue bins (for non-recyclable waste) containing black plastic bags.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following diseases should healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical 
waste be vaccinated against? 666 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against hepatitis 
B and tetanus. These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste. Yearly health 
check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

questions.question:
Question 13: An on-site waste treatment and disposal facility should be built in a hospital if the nearest 
common biomedical treatment facility is:
questions.explanation:
According to biomedical waste management rules of 2016, healthcare establishments shall 
establish an on-site treatment and disposal facility only when a common biomedical treatment 
facility (CBMWTF) is more than 75 km away. According to these rules, biomedical waste (BMW) from healthcare facilities is to be transported 
to a CMBWTF. The establishment of CBMWTF reduces the need for transport and cost of 
treatment/ kg of BMW.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a high-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste?
questions.explanation:
Microwaving is a low-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste. The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are: Low-heat system

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following disposal methods uses high temperature and dry oxidation?
questions.explanation:
Incineration is a high-temperature dry oxidation process. Waste that is incinerated need not undergo any type of pre-treatment. It helps to reduce weight as 
well as volume. The temperature in the incinerator is 800■C in the primary chamber and 1050■C 
in the secondary chamber. Types of incinerators: • Rotary kilns • Single chamber pyrolytic • Double chamber pyrolytic The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are: Low-heat system 
High-heat system Autoclaving:Uses steam. It is

questions.question:
Question 16: In a treatment facility, which of the following cannot be used to verify the treatment of 
biomedical waste done by incineration? 667 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis is not used to verify thermal methods of biomedical waste 
disposal. It is a biological larvicide, used in nonpotable water for killing mosquito larvae. The following can be used to verify the adequacy of thermal methods of biomedical waste 
disposal: • Bacillus atropheus • Bacillus subtilis • Geobacillus stearothermophilus

questions.question:
Question 17: At a waste treatment facility, pharmaceutical waste was mixed with cement, lime, and water 
before disposal. What is this method known as?
questions.explanation:
675 
Sold by @itachibot Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the 
toxicity of the waste and to reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly done 
for incineration ash with high metal content. The typical composition of the inertization mixture is: • 65% pharmaceutical waste • 15% cement • 15% lime • 5% water

questions.question: Question 18: What is the correct combination of temperature and duration used in a hot air oven?
questions.explanation:
The correct combinations of temperature and duration of sterilisation in a hot air oven is: • 180°C for 30 mins • 170°C for 60 mins • 160■C for 2 hours It can be used to sterilize powders, glasswares, and oils. An autoclave is another apparatus that is used for sterilization. It uses steam at a temperature 
of 121■C for 30 mins under 15 lbs of pressure.

questions.question: Question 19: All the following are the characteristics of waste that can be incinerated except:
questions.explanation:
Only waste material containing <5% of noncombustible solids can be incinerated. Wastes that 
are incinerated go in the yellow bag. Waste products with the following characteristics can be incinerated: • Combustible matter >60% • Non-combustible solid <5% • Non-combustible fine <20% • Low heating volume • Moisture content <30%.

questions.question:
Question 20: Correctly match the following logos. 668 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The correctly matched logos are as shown below. 676 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: You are working in a covid ward. After doffing, where will you dispose of the plastic coverall?
questions.explanation:
The plastic coverall used by a healthcare worker during the COVID-19 pandemic should be 
disposed of in the red bin.

questions.question:
Question 22: An intern asks for your advice regarding the disposal of needles from the needle tip cutter 
after a vaccine drive. Which of the following bins will you advise her to discard them in?
questions.explanation:
Waste sharps including metals (both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps) are to be 
discarded in the white bin.

questions.question:
Question 23: Chemical waste is disposed in  
 bags.

options.a: Measures to prevent hazards are designed in mitigation phase
options.b: Rescue and evacuation occur in recovery phase
options.c: Measures on vector control are done in rehabilitation phase

questions.explanation:
Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers or non-chlorinated plastic bags. 677 
Sold by @itachibot Disaster Management
